commit_message:
Vertica cluster user management

Change-Id: I214aa314b4f9bc5abd059d121bab7f7975fa776c
blueprint: cluster-user-management
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-specs refs/changes/76/189976/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode Sections of this template were taken directly from the Nova spec template at: https://github.com/openstack/nova-specs/blob/master/specs/template.rst .. This template should be in ReSTructured text. The filename in the git repository should match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of https://blueprints.launchpad.net/trove/+spec/awesome-thing should be named awesome-thing.rst. Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None Note: This comment may be removed if desired, however the license notice above should remain. =================================== Adding user management for Clusters =================================== We would like to introduce user management for clusters. This would allow the DB admin to perform the CRUD operations on the users. A DB admin can create an user for the cluster, get a list of all the users for a particular cluster. An user added/updated/deleted to a cluster, gets added/updated/deleted to all the instances of that cluster. We can also update and delete any user associated with the cluster. Currently it will be implemented only for the Vertica clusters, with the scope for possible extension in future for other clusters as well. Launchpad Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/trove/+spec/cluster-user-management Problem Description =================== Right now, there is no way to associate a user with a a cluster as we have for instances. So it would be great if we have user management for clusters as well. Proposed Change =============== To implement the changes needed we to incorporate user management to the clusters. This should allow the DB admin to perform the following tasks: 1. create user: user name, password and list of databases(optional) should be passed to create an user. 2. list user: list all users for a specified cluster ID 3. update user: updates a specific user for a cluster 4. delete user: deletes a specific user Configuration ------------- None Database -------- None Public API ---------- Request: - - - - - - POST /v1.0/{tenantId}/clusters{clusterID}/users { "users": [ { "databases": [ { "name": "databaseA" } ], "name": "dbuser3", "password": "secretsecret" }, { "databases": [ { "name": "databaseB" }, { "name": "databaseC" } ], "name": "dbuser4", "password": "secretsecret" } ] } - - - - - - - - Response - - - - - - - - { users: [ { created : 2015-01-29T20:18:23, "databases": [ { "name": "databaseA" } ], "name": "dbuser3", "password": "secretsecret" }' { created : 2015-01-29T20:18:36, "databases": [ { "name": "databaseB" }, { "name": "databaseC" } ], "name": "dbuser4", "password": "secretsecret" } ] } - - - - - - - - Request - - - - - - - - GET /v1.0/{tenantId}/clusters/{clusterId}/users - - - - - - - - Response - - - - - - - - { "users": [ { "databases": [ { "name": "databaseA" } ], "name": "dbuser3" }, { "databases": [ { "name": "databaseB" }, { "name": "databaseC" } ], "name": "dbuser4" } ] } Request: - - - - - - PUT /v1.0/{tenantId}/clusters{clusterID}/users { "users": [ { "databases": [ { "name": "databaseA" } ], "name": "dbuser3", "password": "secretsecret" }, { "databases": [ { "name": "databaseB" }, { "name": "databaseC" } ], "name": "dbuser4", "password": "secretsecret" } ] } - - - - - - - - Response - - - - - - - - { users: [ { created : 2015-01-29T20:18:23, "databases": [ { "name": "databaseA" } ], "name": "dbuser3", "password": "secretsecret" }' { created : 2015-01-29T20:18:36, "databases": [ { "name": "databaseB" }, { "name": "databaseC" } ], "name": "dbuser4", "password": "secretsecret" } ] } - - - - - - - - Request - - - - - - - - DELETE /v1.0/{accountId}/clusters/{clusterId}/users/{name} - - - - - - - - This operation has no response body Public API Security ------------------- None Python API ---------- None CLI (python-troveclient) ------------------------ We need to modify the python-troveclient in order to get the user list, create user, delete user, etc. Currently, the positional argument: ID or name of the instance needs to be modified to ID or name of the instance or cluster. user-create Creates a user on an instance or a cluster. user-delete Deletes a user from an instance or a cluster. user-list Lists the users for an instance or a cluster. user-update-attributes Updates a user's attributes on an instance or a cluster. Internal API ------------ None Guest Agent ----------- The guestagent/datastores needs to be changed to provide implementations for the methods for user management. Alternatives ------------ None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: - mayuri.ganguly@hp.com - sharika.pongubala@hp.com Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: eg. Liberty-1 Work Items ---------- -Add changes to the trove client API -Add implementations to the guestagent/datastores Upgrade Implications ==================== None Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unittests will be added to validate implemented functions. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

commit_message:
User management for Vertica clusters and instances

As the spec specifies, changes were made to
enable user CRUD operations for Vertica clusters
and instances.

To associate a user with a cluster, changes to the
user api. The previous UserController was replaced
with a DatastoreUserController interface that the
VerticaUserController and the MySQLUserController
both implement. The interface has methods for
managing users on both instances and clusters.

Change-Id: I21ebdc8e6ae896ad8241ad296fbb07db862cfd72
Implements blueprint: cluster-user-management

commit_message:
Simplifying provisioning of large homogeneous clusters

Change-Id: Ib45c3f15cad8fdad2d08befefe5f96355a49cd85
Blueprint: provision-large-clusters
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-specs refs/changes/59/182859/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. ========================================== Improve cluster create for large clusters ========================================== Problem description =================== Current cluster create call requires information like flavor, volume size, neutron network etc to be specified on the instance level. Many datastores will enjoy the flexibility offered by the cluster create API call to provide details on the instances level. But at the same time there are datastores where cluster instances will be more homogeneous, where they are restrictive of having same flavor or same volume size for all their instances in the same cluster. Users of such datastores will end up specifying lot of redundant information. Larger the cluster more redundant information will have to be provided. Proposed change =============== Cluster create call starts accepting information for flavor, volume size and neutron network and availability zone on the cluster level. It uses these as the default parameters for all the instances in the cluster. Instance level parameters are also accepted and they get preference over cluster level parameters. Whenever user provides an instance without necessary details like flavor, volume size, neutron network or availability zone we go back to the cluster level parameters and use that information to provision the instance. This will allow the flexibility to be able to customize specific instance in the cluster and will also allow users to not have to specify redundant information on each and every instance in their cluster. -------------- Create Cluster -------------- Request:: POST /v1.0/<tenant_id>/clusters { "cluster": { "name": "vertica-clstr", "datastore": { "type": "vertica", "version": "7.1" }, "flavorRef": "3", "volume": {"size": "10"}, "availability_zone": "az1", "nics": [ { "net-id": "e89aa5fd-6b0a-436d-a75c-1545d34d5331" } ], "instances": [ { }, { "availability_zone": "az2", }, { "availability_zone": "az3", }, { "flavorRef": "2", "volume": { "size": 2 }, "availability_zone": "az3" } ] } } Response:: { "cluster": { "id": "edaac9ca-b5e1-4028-adb7-fa7653e11224", "task": { "id": 2, "name": "BUILDING", "description": "Building the initial cluster." }, "name": "vertica-clstr", "created": "2015-01-29T20:19:23", "updated": "2015-01-29T20:19:23", "links": [{...}], "datastore": { "type": "vertica", "version": "7.1" }, "ip": [], "instances": [ { "id": "416b0b16-ba55-4302-bbd3-ff566032e1c1", "name": "vertica-clstr-member-1", "status": "BUILD", "ip": [], "links": [{...}], "flavor": { "id": "3", "links": [{...}] }, "volume": { "size": 10 } }, { "id": "965ef811-7c1d-47fc-89f2-a89dfdd23ef2", "name": "vertica-clstr-member-2", "status": "BUILD", "ip": [], "links": [{...}], "flavor": { "id": "3", "links": [{...}] }, "volume": { "size": 10 } }, { "id": "3642f41c-e8ad-4164-a089-3891bf7f2d2b", "name": "vertica-clstr-member-3", "status": "BUILD", "ip": [], "links": [{...}], "flavor": { "id": "3", "links": [{...}] }, "volume": { "size": 10 } } { "id": "3642f41c-e8ad-4164-a089-3891bf7f2d2b", "name": "vertica-clstr-member-3", "status": "BUILD", "ip": [], "links": [{...}], "flavor": { "id": "2", "links": [{...}] }, "volume": { "size": 2 } } ] } } Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: - saurabh.surana@hp.com Milestones ---------- "Liberty" Work Items ---------- - Change Trove API schema to accept new parameters on cluster level. - Change datastore specific strategies for vertica and mongodb to accept these new parameters - Changes to trove client to pass new parameters on cluster create Testing ======= Unit tests and integration test for cluster will be updated. Documentation Impact ==================== The docs would need updates for: - Cluster creation API

commit_message:
Custom Flavors For Config Servers and Routers

adds configurations for setting config-server flavor as well
as the query-router flavor for mongodb clusters. prior to this
patch, the routers and config-servers would inherit the flavor
chosen for the instances, which is an extremely inefficient
use of resources.

Change-Id: Iac0803401c30141f5e9d9544bf982597647092d9
Implements: blueprint clustering-sizing

deleted_lines: num_mongos = mongo_conf.num_query_routers_per_cluster delta_instances = num_instances + num_configsvr + num_mongos volume_size = None # TODO(amcreynolds): for now, mongos+configsvr same flavor+disk deltas['volumes'] = volume_size * delta_instances else: # TODO(amcreynolds): is ephemeral possible for mongodb clusters? flavor_id, volume_size, None, mongos_config = {"id": db_info.id, for i in range(1, num_mongos + 1): instance_name = "%s-%s-%s" % (name, "mongos", str(i)) flavor_id, volume_size, None, cluster_config=mongos_config)

commit_message:
Use native Heat template format and resources

This patch starts to move Trove usage of Heat to native Heat templates
and OpenStack resources.

Changes include:
- use native HOT syntax for the template
- use native HOT functions to resolve resources and parameters
- use native OpenStack volume and volume attachment resources
- use native OpenStack server resource

As a consequence of the latter, Trove images no longer should require
heat-cfntools package, boot config is done purely via cloud-init.
*Warning* - the default login name to the instance might no longer
be 'ec2-user' and depends on actual cloud image used.

The resources left untouched are security group and floating ip plus
association as currently in Heat only those AWS-compat resources
support both Nova-network and Neutron backends transparently.

Change-Id: I9bcdf234ccd3881f1ab836542c689da44d592e1c
Implements: blueprint native-os-heat-resources

'}, {'number': 30, 'created': '2015-04-17 20:12:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/f76926a32f7d1e93ba2430cce5c079ef87d20c4c', 'message': 'Add instance metadata functionality to trove

Instance metadata is a feature that has been requested frequently by
Trove users. They need a way to store critical information for their
instances and have that be associated with the instance so that it is
displayed whenever that instance is listed via the API.

This also becomes very usable from a testing perspective when doing
integration/CI. The metadata can be utilized to store things like what
process created the instance, what the instance is being used for, etc.

The following calls have been implemented to facilitate metadata
support:

  create
  delete
  list
  show
  edit
  update

Implements: blueprint trove-metadata

Author: Daniel Salinas <imsplitbit@gmail.com>

Co-Authored-By: Joe Cruz <joe.cruz@rackspace.com>
Co-Authored-By: Denis Makogon <dmakogon@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Peter Stachowski <peter@tesora.com>

Change-Id: I1925b58b0ead307babe57d0ee28dcb5449fd6ce5

commit_message:
Add instance metadata functionality to trove

Instance metadata is a feature that has been requested frequently by
Trove users. They need a way to store critical information for their
instances and have that be associated with the instance so that it is
displayed whenever that instance is listed via the API.

This also becomes very usable from a testing perspective when doing
integration/CI. The metadata can be utilized to store things like what
process created the instance, what the instance is being used for, etc.

The following calls have been implemented to facilitate metadata
support:

  create
  delete
  list
  show
  edit
  update

Implements: blueprint trove-metadata

Author: Daniel Salinas <imsplitbit@gmail.com>

Co-Authored-By: Joe Cruz <joe.cruz@rackspace.com>
Co-Authored-By: Denis Makogon <dmakogon@mirantis.com>
Co-Authored-By: Peter Stachowski <peter@tesora.com>

Change-Id: I1925b58b0ead307babe57d0ee28dcb5449fd6ce5

subject: Fix poll_until retriever while creating an instance
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-02 10:48:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/fa4fba610b99371e95e2f26cf50c2ba07bcc4a09', 'message': "Fix poll_until retriever when heat provisioning is enabled

Reasons:
 - When instance is being launched Trove-Taskmanager tries
   to define Trove instance status and Compute Instance status.
   But if heat provisioning is enabled, Trove should check status
   of its Instance and status of Stack, because checking status of
   Compute instance only is not enough, since Stack contains
   more than one resource.
 - Since taskmanager waiting for stack status
   'CREATE_COMPLETE'/'CREATE_FAILED' at provisioning,
   no need to pull Compute Instance status inside method
   _service_is_active method.
   Just need to poll Trove Instance status.

Changes:
 - splitting _service_is_active into:
   - trove_instance_is_active;
   - _compute_instance_is_active.
 - updating poll_intil retriever when heat provisioning enabled.

Change-Id: I63cfde596c15208563640d199f1d4a50bc1db668
Closes-Bug: #1325512
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-06-04 12:19:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/64e4eed095485961c956f2d0577b0666142ac946', 'message': "Fix poll_until retriever when heat provisioning is enabled

Reasons:
 - When instance is being launched Trove-Taskmanager tries
   to define Trove instance status and Compute Instance status.
   But if heat provisioning is enabled, Trove should check status
   of its Instance and status of Stack, because checking status of
   Compute instance only is not enough, since Stack contains
   more than one resource.
 - Since taskmanager waiting for stack status
   'CREATE_COMPLETE'/'CREATE_FAILED' at provisioning,
   no need to pull Compute Instance status inside method
   _service_is_active method.
   Just need to poll Trove Instance status.

Changes:
 - splitting _service_is_active into:
   - trove_instance_is_active;
   - _compute_instance_is_active.
 - updating poll_intil retriever when heat provisioning enabled.

Change-Id: I63cfde596c15208563640d199f1d4a50bc1db668
Closes-Bug: #1325512
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2014-06-18 08:58:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/26a7aa768e8ea58d6ba770fde11b9f5d03857bf2', 'message': "Fix poll_until retriever when heat provisioning is enabled

Reasons:
 - When instance is being launched Trove-Taskmanager tries
   to define Trove instance status and Compute Instance status.
   But if heat provisioning was enabled, Trove should check status
   of its Instance only since _create_server_volume_heat finishes
   with stack that's already in appropriate state - no need to check
   Compute Instance status at all.
 - Since taskmanager waiting for stack status
   'CREATE_COMPLETE'/'CREATE_FAILED' at provisioning,
   no need to pull Compute Instance status inside poll_until, because
   for heat-based provisioning is enough to poll
   and verify Instance Service status.

Changes:
 - extracting Trove instance retriever from _service_is_active into:
   - _check_trove_instance_is_in_valid_state;
 - updating poll_intil retriever when heat provisioning enabled.

Change-Id: I63cfde596c15208563640d199f1d4a50bc1db668
Closes-Bug: #1325512
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2014-06-19 09:14:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/39240b6c9ce4f6a52e9b15eb449b8f2245e6525b', 'message': "Fix poll_until retriever when heat provisioning is enabled

Reasons:
 - When instance is being launched Trove-Taskmanager tries
   to define Trove instance status and Compute Instance status.
   But if heat provisioning was enabled, Trove should check status
   of its Instance only since _create_server_volume_heat finishes
   with stack that's already in appropriate state - no need to check
   Compute Instance status at all.
 - Since taskmanager waiting for stack status
   'CREATE_COMPLETE'/'CREATE_FAILED' at provisioning,
   no need to pull Compute Instance status inside poll_until, because
   for heat-based provisioning is enough to poll
   and verify Instance Service status.

Changes:
 - removing _service_is_active method;
 - splitting _service_is_active into:
   - _check_trove_instance_is_active;
   - _check_compute_instance_is_active.
 - updating _create_server method to poll compute instance status
   until it's ACTIVE or fail with appropriate exception;
 - updating poller to ask only for Trove instance status after
   stack/instance was created and in ACTIVE state.

Change-Id: I63cfde596c15208563640d199f1d4a50bc1db668
Closes-Bug: #1325512

   Compute Instance status at all.

   'CREATE_COMPLETE'/'CREATE_FAILED' at provisioning,
   no need to pull Compute Instance status inside poll_until, because
   for heat-based provisioning is enough to poll
   and verify Instance Service status;
 - Taskmanager should block following provisioning
    steps of received compute instance is not ACTIVE.

commit_message:
Fix poll_until retriever while creating an instance

Reasons:
 - When instance is being launched Trove-Taskmanager tries
   to define Trove instance status and Compute Instance status.
   But if heat provisioning was enabled, Trove should check status
   of its Instance only since _create_server_volume_heat finishes
   with stack that's already in appropriate state - no need to check
   Compute Instance status at all.
 - Since taskmanager waiting for stack status
   'CREATE_COMPLETE'/'CREATE_FAILED' at provisioning,
   no need to pull Compute Instance status inside poll_until, because
   for heat-based provisioning is enough to poll
   and verify Instance Service status;
 - Taskmanager should block following provisioning
    steps of received compute instance is not ACTIVE.

Changes:
 - removing _service_is_active method;
 - splitting _service_is_active into:
   - _check_trove_instance_is_active;
   - _check_compute_instance_is_active.
 - updating _create_server method to poll compute instance status
   until it's ACTIVE or fail with appropriate exception;
 - updating poller to ask only for Trove instance status after
   stack/instance was created and in ACTIVE state.
 - _verify_compute_instance_is_active method was added to:
   - _create_server_volume;
   - _create_server_volume_individually;

Change-Id: I63cfde596c15208563640d199f1d4a50bc1db668
Closes-Bug: #1325512
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/94/97194/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: method_to_call = (self._service_is_active if not use_heat else self._trove_instance_is_active) utils.poll_until(method_to_call, def _trove_instance_is_active(self): service = InstanceServiceStatus.find_by(instance_id=self.id) status = service.get_status() if status == rd_instance.ServiceStatuses.RUNNING: return True elif status not in [rd_instance.ServiceStatuses.NEW, rd_instance.ServiceStatuses.BUILDING]: raise TroveError(_("Service not active, status: %s") % status) def _compute_instance_is_active(self): c_id = self.db_info.compute_instance_id nova_status = self.nova_client.servers.get(c_id).status if nova_status in [InstanceStatus.ERROR, InstanceStatus.FAILED]: raise TroveError(_("Server not active, status: %s") % nova_status) return False trove_instance_status = self._trove_instance_is_active() if trove_instance_status: return trove_instance_status nova_instance_status = self._compute_instance_is_active() if not nova_instance_status: return nova_instance_status
deleted_lines: utils.poll_until(self._service_is_active, service = InstanceServiceStatus.find_by(instance_id=self.id) status = service.get_status() if status == rd_instance.ServiceStatuses.RUNNING: return True elif status not in [rd_instance.ServiceStatuses.NEW, rd_instance.ServiceStatuses.BUILDING]: raise TroveError(_("Service not active, status: %s") % status) c_id = self.db_info.compute_instance_id nova_status = self.nova_client.servers.get(c_id).status if nova_status in [InstanceStatus.ERROR, InstanceStatus.FAILED]: raise TroveError(_("Server not active, status: %s") % nova_status) return False

commit_message:
Corrects error message for user-access-revoke

Reasons:
- Before revoking the requested database access, current code checks
  whether user has intended access, in the absence of which, service
  prompts the wrong message to user, that database does not exists.
- The error is raised as HTTP 422, unprocessable.

Changes:
- Added new HTTP 422 access forbidden exception to
  inform the lack of access.
- Unit-tests added.
- Integration test updated to verify HTTP-422.

Change-Id: Ifc3010c20324e05a002f674865150c96c331fde3
Closes-Bug: #1302405

commit_message:
Add datastore version and type to backup-list and backup-show

The backup-show and backup-list commands do not show the datastore type
and version, this patch includes it in the list.

Change-Id: I7ca912fa04df94126f509e85e9631d1be1ccaf13
Closes-Bug: #1340367
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-troveclient refs/changes/25/144325/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: backup._info['datastore'] = backup.datastore['type'] backup._info['datastore_version'] = backup.datastore['version'] for backup in backups: if hasattr(backup, 'datastore'): setattr(backup, 'datastore_version', backup.datastore['version']) setattr(backup, 'datastore', backup.datastore['type']) utils.print_list(backups, ['id', 'instance_id', 'name', 'datastore', 'datastore_version',

commit_message:
Readonly functional tests in trove CLI

This patch implements readonly functional tests using trove CLI.
All the unit tests are moved to "unit" directory under "tests" directory.
Functional tests are under "functional" directory under "tests".
Implements: blueprint functional-test-coverage
Depends-On: I60812c49577948bf1bb8a55bbea321e5690f0954
Change-Id: I2d439fa44c686837c9924f154ed5f0d03f6ce911

commit_message:
Adding licensing support for clusters and instances

Introducing licensing support by creating a separate
top level resource for licenses. This would allow
users to BYOL (bring your own license) and to associate
licenses with a particular datastore version.

Change-Id: Ia8b5f920fcc48df0de5dab52166aeab38b67d2a2
Blueprint: trove-license-installation
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-specs refs/changes/17/187817/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1347\cocoasubrtf570 {\fonttbl\f0\fswiss\fcharset0 Helvetica;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;} \margl1440\margr1440\vieww22180\viewh13800\viewkind0 \pard\tx720\tx1440\tx2160\tx2880\tx3600\tx4320\tx5040\tx5760\tx6480\tx7200\tx7920\tx8640\pardirnatural \f0\fs24 \cf0 \ ========================\ Integration of licensing support\ ========================\ \ \pard\tx720\tx1440\tx2160\tx2880\tx3600\tx4320\tx5040\tx5760\tx6480\tx7200\tx7920\tx8640\pardirnatural \b \cf0 Introduction \b0 \ \ We would like to introduce licensing support in trove by creating a separate top level resource\ for licenses. This would allow users to associate licenses with a particular datastore version.\ The license can be configured upon installation of the datastore or added later. This would\ allow for a better tracking of clusters or instances associated to a specific license. A license\ can be added at any time. Additionally, a license can be modified/deleted if no running instance\ is associated with it at the time. The details for implementation of this feature are\ detailed in this specification.\ \ Launchpad Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/trove/+spec/trove-license-installation\ \ ========================================================================\ \ \b Description \b0 \ \ Currently, there is no way of associating a license with a datastore version. To implement this,\ it is imperative that a separate schema of licensing information be created. A particular license\ may have many datastore versions it belongs to, so another table must be added which stores\ the one-to-many relationship between license IDs and datastore version(s) it is associated with.\ Upon cluster/instance creation, the license ID must be specified in order to associate it to\ a single instance or a cluster. By default, if no license ID is specified then there is no license\ associated to the instance/cluster. When adding a new license the datastore type and\ datastore version must be specified. When deleting/updating a license, there must be no\ running instances using that associated license.\ \ =========================================================================\ \ \b Proposal \b0 \ \ To implement the changes needed to incorporate licenses in trove, a separate database table for licenses\ would be required. This database table will have license ID as the primary key which will be used to identify\ a particular license. Each license object will also have a multiple datastore versions to which it is associated,\ some metadata, the actual license key, and a license name for users\'92 understanding. \expnd0\expndtw0\kerning0 Tenant ID will\ control who has access to the license, if tenant ID is NULL then license will be public and can be used by any\ tenant. When user adds the\'a0license, their tenant ID will be associated with the license. When an admin\ uses trove-manage to add a license, they can specify any tenant\'a0ID to be associated with the license\ or can specify NULL to make it public. Also, \kerning1\expnd0\expndtw0 the trove-cli for creating a cluster and updating a\ cluster will have to be modified.\ \ ==========================================================================\ \ \b Database \b0 \ \ The implementation would require a new licenses database table. The attribute \'91licenseID\'92\ is the primary key for each license in the licenses table. Also, in many cases a license might have\ multiple datastore versions it is associated with. Therefore, another table for datastore versions\ and license IDs should be created. License ID needs to be added as a referential key to tables\ which will be associated to licenses.\ \ ===========================================================================\ \ \b Public API\ commit_message:
Make Rsync For Guest Optional

add additional elements in trove-integration to stage the trove code
and trove-guestagent.conf for the guest in the extra-data.d hook, and
subsequently install them in the install.d hook, vs. relying on
upstart/systemd to rsync it.

Change-Id: I960c4cf415ca427df07c48865f1ebc9e20a548a9
Implements: blueprint rsync-optional

subject: Support CentOS in postgresql config.py path
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-09 22:26:22.000000000', 'files': ['trove/guestagent/datastore/experimental/postgresql/service/config.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/5797d88ba056d9845595a85957e8ff7cf0abfb51', 'message': "Support CentOS in postgresql config.py path

The PGSQL_CONFIG and PSQL_HBA_CONFIG values need specific
assignment for the 'redhat' family (CentOS, RHEL, Fedora).
The locations of those conf files are defaulted to their
normal location after a call to initdb (/var/lib/pgsql/data).

Change-Id: Ib27f1052291f3ef57e967db7393e70821a7e350e
Closes-Bug: #1442387
"}]
commit_message:
Support CentOS in postgresql config.py path

The PGSQL_CONFIG and PSQL_HBA_CONFIG values need specific
assignment for the 'redhat' family (CentOS, RHEL, Fedora).
The locations of those conf files are defaulted to their
normal location after a call to initdb (/var/lib/pgsql/data).

Change-Id: Ib27f1052291f3ef57e967db7393e70821a7e350e
Closes-Bug: #1442387
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/28/172228/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from trove.guestagent.common.operating_system import get_osOS = get_os()""" Note the redhat conf files are generated by initdb """ if OS is 'redhat': PGSQL_CONFIG = "/var/lib/pgsql/data/postgresql.conf" PGSQL_HBA_CONFIG = "/var/lib/pgsql/data/pg_hba.conf"

- In the absence of the exception handler block in resize-volume-execute method,
  the trove guest was not returning to it original state
  in case of a failure of any guest-methods,
  like if stop_db fails instance gets stuck in resize state.

- Adds the exception handler block to handle any GuestError.
- Removes the status checking block from the same method,
  as there was no purpose of this part because instance is pre-validated
  before sending a resize call for its "ACTIVE" state,

Change-Id: I538513552531f6d302c037b3ae9a315e6bbe2008

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-04-08 11:12:29.000000000', 'files': ['trove/taskmanager/models.py', 'trove/tests/unittests/taskmanager/test_models.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/b7258c643eaca645f9e528ad61ae5668f5fa1e5d', 'message': 'Adds guest-exception-handler to resize-volume

- Adds the exception handler block to handle any GuestError.
- Removes the status checking block from the same method,

commit_message:
Adds guest-exception-handler to resize-volume

- In the absence of the exception handler block in resize-volume-execute
  method, the trove guest was not returning to it original state
  in case of a failure of any guest-methods,
  like if stop_db fails instance gets stuck in resize state.

- Adds the exception handler block to handle any GuestError.
- Removes the status checking block from the same method,
  as there was no purpose of this part because instance is pre-validated
  before sending a resize call for its "ACTIVE" state,
  in simple words, if instance status was not "ACTIVE"
  code will not flow till this point.
- Removes the test which was testing the execute method raising exception
  when called with an instance in ERROR state.

Change-Id: I538513552531f6d302c037b3ae9a315e6bbe2008
Closes-Bug: #1441558

commit_message:
add client management support

Right now the client does not support mgmt api.
So add code to support them. We now support quota,
management, mgmt_cluster, accounts, mgmt_config_params.

Change-Id: I521f1bdc7b83c408e2d38a18296b519b4e24d843
Closes-Bug: #1250258

subject: Remove quotes from subshell call in tools/with_venv.sh
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-07 13:20:37.000000000', 'files': ['tools/with_venv.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/3fee30005058248b5427a3e7b5b62a3d6a201e70', 'message': 'Remove quotes from subshell call in tools/with_venv.sh

Always no quotes for $() statement.

We don't need quotes to hold blanks in result:
 # i=$(echo 1 2 3)
 # echo $i
 1 2 3
 #

These quotes can make something wrong in some case:
 # i=$(echo '!')
 #
 # i="$(echo '!')"
 -bash: !: event not found
 #

No real problem for current code in with_venv.sh, only to use a
better code style.

Change-Id: Ic0d613235fbfeb3c6aed93c55cbb8fd117b365c4
Signed-off-by: Zhao Lei <zhaolei@cn.fujitsu.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Remove quotes from subshell call in tools/with_venv.sh

Always no quotes for $() statement.

We don't need quotes to hold blanks in result:
 # i=$(echo 1 2 3)
 # echo $i
 1 2 3
 #

These quotes can make something wrong in some case:
 # i=$(echo '!')
 #
 # i="$(echo '!')"
 -bash: !: event not found
 #

No real problem for current code in with_venv.sh, only to use a
better code style.

Change-Id: Ic0d613235fbfeb3c6aed93c55cbb8fd117b365c4
Signed-off-by: Zhao Lei <zhaolei@cn.fujitsu.com>

commit_message:
Allow user to select zone for their trove volume

In multi cinder zone environment, trove have volume-type support,
but does not have zone support.For Instance,if I have two cinder zone:dmz,dev
and two kind of volume in each zone:ssd,ceph.
If I only want to create trove volume in my dmz zone ssd volume , Now I cant't.
I have to reconfigure cinder to create a new volume type
to distinguish ssd in dmz from ssd others, it's very uncomfortable.

Change-Id: I4d9aeaca1cecbe5e6d4ce31eaf8802c65596e581
Closes-Bug: #1482162

commit_message:
Add support for Microsoft SQL Server datastore in Trove

Add Microsoft SQL Server datastore for Trove in addition to the
existing datastores currently supported.

The guestagent will run on Windows and include functions
like launch, terminate, resize instance and more advanced features,
like backup, restore, clustering and replication.

Blueprint: mssql-server-db-support

Change-Id: I72a90d7ab141670d4219c53e16766823d95bd0e5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-specs refs/changes/81/164881/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode Sections of this template were taken directly from the Nova spec template at: https://github.com/openstack/nova-specs/blob/master/specs/template.rst .. ======================================= Microsoft SQL Server Datastore support ======================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/trove/+spec/mssql-server-support Microsoft SQL Server is a proven, predictable performance database server, provided by Microsoft. As Trove aims to become a production DBaaS, its abilities should comprise also Microsoft database technology. See more information at:: http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/server-cloud/products/sql-server/ Problem description =================== In order to meet the users' need in OpenStack, Trove should support Microsoft SQL Server. Proposed change =============== For the initial implementation, Microsoft SQL Server will support minimum working cases and gradually acquire full compatibility. With respect to datastore compatibility matrix, Microsoft SQL Server support will include(regular):: launch reboot terminate terminate resize backup restore clustering users API databases API root API replication To support Microsoft SQL Server by Trove, the following changes will be added:: "guestagent manager" - handles deployment and management of Microsoft SQL Server instance "backup strategy" - handles backuping/restoring procedure for Microsoft SQL Server "replication strategy" - handles replication procedure for Microsoft SQL Server "storage strategy" - handles storage procedure for Microsoft SQL Server The following Microsoft SQL Server versions will be supported:: Versions: 2012,2014 Editions: Express, Web, Standard, Enterprise Some features will be limited by the actual edition limitations. Configuration ------------- Each datastore requires its own configuration group. Next options should be added to cover needed configurations:: tcp_ports upd_ports mount_point usage_timeout volume_support device_path Database -------- None Public API ---------- None Public API Security ------------------- None Internal API ------------ None Guest Agent ----------- Add support to the Guest Agent for the following Windows versions:: Windows Server 2008 R2 Windows Server 2012 Windows Server 2012 R2 Windows 8 Windows 8.1 Alternatives ------------ None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee:: Launchpad: avladu IRC: avladu Email: avladu@cloudbasesolutions.com Milestones ---------- Liberty Work Items ---------- List of items to develop:: DIB elements development guestagent manager development backup/restore feature development replication feature development storage feature development Upgrade Implications ==================== None Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Microsoft SQL Server support will include:: unit testing integration testing Continuous integration testing will be provided by the Microsoft Hyper-V CI. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== Microsoft SQL Server documentation https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb545450.aspx

commit_message:
New release for pylockfile

Next attempt at releasing pylockfile. 0.12.0 and
0.12.1 did not end up on pypi.

0.12.0 - pypi-extract-universal.py used an old config option
         [wheel]/universal and did not support the newer
         [bdist_wheel/universal. We tried to fix this in
         change id:
         I519acfc3080938fe0445705fc98df12201036c30
         I68b0cd547caf0c9161c983e7dc0f2259a96af762
0.12.1 - We tried this with the same SHA which failed again
         as there was a typo in the previous change. The new
         fix as made in:
         I68b0cd547caf0c9161c983e7dc0f2259a96af762

Another problem was that gate-releases-tox-validate was
tripping when we used the same SHA for 0.12.0 and 0.12.1
So we touched up the README.rst of pylockfile to change
the SHA to make a new release for 0.12.2. Also, since
0.12.0 and 0.12.1 did not end up on pypi, we don't need
to list them here as well.

Change-Id: I8a94287a09c4ebbb5f5cbb661750a9d9cc5e036d

commit_message:
Fix the value meta for http_status metrics

Make sure that the value meta errors have the correct value and
limiting that to the api limit for value meta values

Change-Id: Ifb1d112959bbc7f1c83a1895391d6447188b01a1

commit_message:
Use sudo for role testing

There are 2 ways to realize the privilege escalation
needed for the gate jobs.

1) Editing the playbooks (and hope to not forget to
write the sudo/become lines for every role)
2) Editing the inventory and set the variable there.

I'm taking the second approach with the minimum set
of variables (become_method is sudo by default and
become_user is root by default).

Change-Id: I54b8c1489bfc46d4a03c907f4a86f0313c7778ff

commit_message:
Fix v2 qos-key command

As part of commit 0d2bf657ae5271a01e9ec84d379d17910b263b7e,
qos-key command's v2 support got broken again reintroducing
bug #1284321.

Change-Id: I30d60b060bd1b161bc96c4a529f4732b9ceef90d
Closes-Bug: 1284321

sporadically in the gate.

commit_message:
Remove the TestRemoteObject class

This class is now testing only things that exist (and are tested) in
oslo.versionedobjects. Remove this class from what we test in nova.

Change-Id: I2e64f5917fb83eaa29970388359ef29db44f0e0b

commit_message:
ovs: Make interface name hashing algorithm common and extend it

The OVS device name hashing algorithm shortens interface names that are too
long. To ensure uniqueness it makes use of a hashing algorithm.

Move this function to a common place where it can be shared between ml2
drivers and agents.

Extend the function to support defining the max device length to be used.

Change LOG level to info to help deployers figuring out the unhashed name
of an hashed inteface.

Adapt OVS agent to use this common function instead of its
own implementation.

Change-Id: I5c04f39928d070aa7e372934fcb2675609d2761c
Partial-Bug: #1495960

commit_message:
Removing wait() when initializing notification listener

According to [1],the correct usage is to call stop() before wait(), so in
mistral case, we should never call stop() and wait() in initialization of
engine and executor service.

[1]:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.messaging/notification_listener.html

Change-Id: Ic6a802bff35a6a6fdfadf38474782efd12fd34d8
Closes-Bug: #1514459

subject: Fix state change on exception during task state change
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-25 06:49:08.000000000', 'files': ['mistral/tests/unit/engine/test_direct_workflow.py', 'mistral/engine/default_engine.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/mistral/commit/84c46be347863d285f17afb61fadea5b60bafa0d', 'message': 'Fix state change on exception during task state change

If there is an exception during on_task_state_change, particularly if
there is a YAQL evaluation error in the input of the next task, the state
of the current task and related action execution will be marked ERROR for
sync task and rolled back for async task, leaving the task as orphaned in
RUNNING state in most cases. This is a workflow handling error and the
workflow execution state is already marked ERROR. The state of the current
task execution should not be affected.

Change-Id: Id28b0661c09efa80a666d9eb7606fb435641a989
Closes-Bug: #1510738
(cherry picked from commit 93b19335f5992f74ac0edcd4f95c0ad06d101b74)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix state change on exception during task state change

If there is an exception during on_task_state_change, particularly if
there is a YAQL evaluation error in the input of the next task, the state
of the current task and related action execution will be marked ERROR for
sync task and rolled back for async task, leaving the task as orphaned in
RUNNING state in most cases. This is a workflow handling error and the
workflow execution state is already marked ERROR. The state of the current
task execution should not be affected.

Change-Id: Id28b0661c09efa80a666d9eb7606fb435641a989
Closes-Bug: #1510738
(cherry picked from commit 93b19335f5992f74ac0edcd4f95c0ad06d101b74)

commit_message:
Only log errors in exceptions on demand

Rather than error logging all of them, allow the user a mechanism
to error log the ones they care about. Also make inner_exception
public so that people can make their own choices.

Change-Id: I15973f52d3d68c24ac8ef7643a53ff0118e892cf

commit_message:
Update requirements to suit the existence of lxc vg

If lxc volume group exists, the aio will try to use
this volume group to create the containers.

As one container will use a hard 5GB of storage, and
the fact that (by default) there is more than 16
containers, you'll exhaust all your storage space
and the aio build will fail.

This commit should make this failure more clear to
openstack-ansible users.

The amount of disk is counted with the default
install.

Change-Id: I84f68a24423f9e7046b1235ef51bf2291708fcec
(cherry picked from commit dfc544fed974c81d7542ff8167d6a4143914c79c)

commit_message:
Output the SSL Certificate and Key modulus

Provides a simple mechanism to verify the correct certificates
landed.

A quick and simple way to verify SSL certificates were generated for
a given key is by comparing the modulus of the two.  By outputing
the key modulus and certificate modulus we offer a way to verify
that the right cert and key have been deployed without compromising
any of the secrets.

Change-Id: I882c9840719a09795ba8057a19b0b3985e036c3c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/74/241574/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: cert_modulus - name: key_modulus openssl x509 -noout -modulus -in ${cert_path} > ${heat_outputs_path}.cert_modulus openssl rsa -noout -modulus -in ${cert_path} > ${heat_outputs_path}.key_modulus key_modulus: description: Key SSL Modulus value: {get_attr: [ControllerTLSDeployment, key_modulus]} cert_modulus: description: Certificate SSL Modulus value: {get_attr: [ControllerTLSDeployment, cert_modulus]}

commit_message:
Enable trust anchor injection

This commit enables the injection of a trust anchor or root
certificate into every node in the overcloud. This is in case that the
TLS certificates for the controllers are signed with a self-signed CA
or if the deployer would like to inject a relevant root certificate
for other purposes. In this case the other nodes might need to have
the root certificate in their trust chain in order to do proper
validation

Change-Id: Ia45180fe0bb979cf12d19f039dbfd22e26fb4856

commit_message:
New git dotfiles for independant repository

This will make git review workflow work within this role
This will also prevent undesired files.

Change-Id: I2482314d50cff8f72febf853018d1c6e212216e9

subject: Inject TLS certificate and keys for the Overcloud
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-07 11:33:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/125eee52477fe47259deff53b3873e8d849b831e', 'message': 'Enable TLS deployment for the Overcloud

This is a first implementation of adding TLS termination to the load
balancer in the controllers. The implementation was made so that the
appropriate certificate/private key in PEM format is copied to the
controllers via cloud-init. And the path is then referenced on the
HAProxy configuration.

It might also be needed to install proper trust anchors for those
certificates to work; So such a capability was added in a similar
fashion.

Change-Id: I0ba8e38d75a0c628d8132a66dc25a30fc5183c79

commit_message:
Inject TLS certificate and keys for the Overcloud

This is a first implementation of adding TLS termination to the load
balancer in the controllers. The implementation was made so that the
appropriate certificate/private key in PEM format is copied to the
appropriate controller(s) via a software deployment resource.

And the path is then referenced on the HAProxy configuration, but this
part was left commented out because we need to be able to configure the
keystone endpoints in order for this to work properly.

Change-Id: I0ba8e38d75a0c628d8132a66dc25a30fc5183c79
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/30/231930/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: heat_template_version: 2015-04-30 description: > This is a template which will build the TLS Certificates necessary for the load balancer using the given parameters. parameters: # Can be overriden via parameter_defaults in the environment SSLCertificate: default: '' description: If set, the contents of an SSL certificate .crt file for encrypting SSL endpoints. type: string hidden: true SSLIntermediateCertificates: default: '' description: If set, the contents of an SSL intermediate certificates in PEM format. type: string hidden: true SSLCertificatePath: description: The filepath of the certificate as it will be stored in the controller. type: string default: '/etc/pki/tls/private/overcloud_endpoint.pem' hidden: true SSLKey: default: '' description: If set, the contents of an SSL certificate .key file for encrypting SSL endpoints. type: string hidden: true resources: userdata: type: OS::Heat::MultipartMime properties: parts: - config: {get_resource: controller_ssl_config} controller_ssl_config: type: OS::Heat::CloudConfig properties: cloud_config: write_files: - path: {get_param: SSLCertificatePath} permissions: 0440 owner: root:haproxy content: list_join: - '' - - {get_param: SSLCertificate} - {get_param: SSLIntermediateCertificates} - {get_param: SSLKey} outputs: OS::stack_id: value: {get_resource: userdata}

subject: Use sudo for role testing

commit_message:
Use sudo for role testing

There are 2 ways to realize the privilege escalation needed
for the gate jobs.

1) Editing the playbooks (and hope to not forget to write the
sudo/become lines for every role)
2) Editing the inventory and set the variable there.

I'm taking the second approach with the minimum
set of variables (become_method is sudo by default
and become_user is root by default).

Change-Id: I4f7d423ad2d21611c466ec6bb58d45c5a2fd00b9

commit_message:
config options: remove invalid help text assignment

config options help texts won't get translated. This patch set
removes the translation helper. It also removes the assignment
of a help text as a tuple.

Change-Id: Iecea9576154fef8e1d4d8f3d2635bbb30cad2f7f

Move install-types doc to user guide

Install-types are a user facing feature, not just for developers. Lets
move the docs on them in to the user guide.

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-25 16:35:29.000000000', 'files': ['requirements.txt'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-calico/commit/35ffc79a9ac73c2d4a192ac2fa7996f0bf3ce67c', 'message': "Remove 'sqlalchemy' from requirements.txt

Having that requirement here can cause installation problems - please
see the bug for details.

networking-calico does use sqlalchemy, but it works fine to allow it
to be pulled in by Neutron, and so not to depend explicitly upon it.

Change-Id: I21b17844df0c369d743e18c9bfd41fc4255b4b3e
Closes-Bug: #1519884

commit_message:
Remove 'sqlalchemy' from requirements.txt

Having that requirement here can cause installation problems - please
see the bug for details.

networking-calico does use sqlalchemy, but it works fine to allow it
to be pulled in by Neutron, and so not to depend explicitly upon it.

Change-Id: I21b17844df0c369d743e18c9bfd41fc4255b4b3e
Closes-Bug: #1519884

commit_message:
Handle NO_DOMAIN status

Previous to this patch, when MiniDNS got a `NO_DOMAIN` status back,
it didn't do anything to handle it. Domains just hung in ERROR.

closes-bug: #1416264

Conflicts:
	designate/tests/unit/test_central/test_basic.py

Change-Id: I4348f714868f38c2549c516fe83cce608c0c8d59
(cherry picked from commit ed2861a0193e2b5ebbb89a8d8fb04fdded976483)

The ssh args that we have been carrying are overriding
base functionality in Ansible which can cause intermitent
issues. To correct this issue I removed our ssh-args which

Change-Id: If61d875a58e466ec07cb6818040e83f1612b4f18

Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Remove ssh args to ensure pipelining is working

The ssh args that we have been carrying are overriding
base functionality in Ansible which can cause intermitent
issues. To correct this issue I removed our ssh-args which
will use the default ssh arguments provided by ansible core.

Change-Id: If61d875a58e466ec07cb6818040e83f1612b4f18
Related-Bug: https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/9246
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/48/249348/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: ssh_args = -o ControlMaster=auto -o ControlPersist=60s -o TCPKeepAlive=yes -o ServerAliveInterval=5 -o ServerAliveCountMax=3

commit_message:
[WIP] Move simple nodes operations out of manager.py

This is the second patch in a chain of refactoring patches in preparation
for moving to Futurist library. See blueprint futurist for details.

New mixin class node_ops.NodeOps is added with the moved operations.

Change-Id: I3c58a2ef1083c7d4f18ff5950c785695b179e2aa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/75/235975/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Basic operations on nodes unrelated to provisioning.""" from oslo_log import log import oslo_messaging as messaging from oslo_utils import excutils from ironic.common import exception from ironic.common.i18n import _ from ironic.common.i18n import _LE from ironic.common.i18n import _LI from ironic.common.i18n import _LW from ironic.common import states from ironic.conductor import task_manager from ironic.conductor import utils LOG = log.getLogger(__name__) class NodeOps(object): """A mixin class containing node operations.""" @messaging.expected_exceptions(exception.InvalidParameterValue, exception.MissingParameterValue, exception.NodeLocked) def update_node(self, context, node_obj): """Update a node with the supplied data. This method is the main "hub" for PUT and PATCH requests in the API. It ensures that the requested change is safe to perform, validates the parameters with the node's driver, if necessary. :param context: an admin context :param node_obj: a changed (but not saved) node object. """ node_id = node_obj.uuid LOG.debug("RPC update_node called for node %s." % node_id) # NOTE(jroll) clear maintenance_reason if node.update sets # maintenance to False for backwards compatibility, for tools # not using the maintenance endpoint. delta = node_obj.obj_what_changed() if 'maintenance' in delta and not node_obj.maintenance: node_obj.maintenance_reason = None driver_name = node_obj.driver if 'driver' in delta else None with task_manager.acquire(context, node_id, shared=False, driver_name=driver_name, purpose='node update'): node_obj.save() return node_obj @messaging.expected_exceptions(exception.InvalidParameterValue, exception.MissingParameterValue, exception.NoFreeConductorWorker, exception.NodeLocked) def change_node_power_state(self, context, node_id, new_state): """RPC method to encapsulate changes to a node's state. Perform actions such as power on, power off. The validation is performed synchronously, and if successful, the power action is updated in the background (asynchronously). Once the power action is finished and successful, it updates the power_state for the node with the new power state. :param context: an admin context. :param node_id: the id or uuid of a node. :param new_state: the desired power state of the node. :raises: NoFreeConductorWorker when there is no free worker to start async task. """ LOG.debug("RPC change_node_power_state called for node %(node)s. " "The desired new state is %(state)s." % {'node': node_id, 'state': new_state}) with task_manager.acquire(context, node_id, shared=False, purpose='changing node power state') as task: task.driver.power.validate(task) # Set the target_power_state and clear any last_error, since we're # starting a new operation. This will expose to other processes # and clients that work is in progress. if new_state == states.REBOOT: task.node.target_power_state = states.POWER_ON else: task.node.target_power_state = new_state task.node.last_error = None task.node.save() task.set_spawn_error_hook(utils.power_state_error_handler, task.node, task.node.power_state) task.spawn_after(self._spawn_worker, utils.node_power_action, task, new_state) @messaging.expected_exceptions(exception.NodeLocked, exception.NodeAssociated, exception.InvalidState) def destroy_node(self, context, node_id): """Delete a node. :param context: request context. :param node_id: node id or uuid. :raises: NodeLocked if node is locked by another conductor. :raises: NodeAssociated if the node contains an instance associated with it. :raises: InvalidState if the node is in the wrong provision state to perform deletion. """ # NOTE(dtantsur): we allow deleting a node in maintenance mode even if # we would disallow it otherwise. That's done for recoveting hopelessly # broken nodes (e.g. with broken BMC). with task_manager.acquire(context, node_id, purpose='node deletion') as task: node = task.node if not node.maintenance and node.instance_uuid is not None: raise exception.NodeAssociated(node=node.uuid, instance=node.instance_uuid) # NOTE(lucasagomes): For the *FAIL states we users should # move it to a safe state prior to deletion. This is because we # should try to avoid deleting a node in a dirty/whacky state, # e.g: A node in DEPLOYFAIL, if deleted without passing through # tear down/cleaning may leave data from the previous tenant # in the disk. So nodes in *FAIL states should first be moved to: # CLEANFAIL -> MANAGEABLE # INSPECTIONFAIL -> MANAGEABLE # DEPLOYFAIL -> DELETING # ZAPFAIL -> MANAGEABLE (in the future) if (not node.maintenance and node.provision_state not in states.DELETE_ALLOWED_STATES): msg = (_('Can not delete node "%(node)s" while it is in ' 'provision state "%(state)s". Valid provision states ' 'to perform deletion are: "%(valid_states)s"') % {'node': node.uuid, 'state': node.provision_state, 'valid_states': states.DELETE_ALLOWED_STATES}) raise exception.InvalidState(msg) if node.console_enabled: try: task.driver.console.stop_console(task) except Exception as err: LOG.error(_LE('Failed to stop console while deleting ' 'the node %(node)s: %(err)s.'), {'node': node.uuid, 'err': err}) node.destroy() LOG.info(_LI('Successfully deleted node %(node)s.'), {'node': node.uuid}) @messaging.expected_exceptions(exception.NodeLocked, exception.UnsupportedDriverExtension, exception.NodeConsoleNotEnabled, exception.InvalidParameterValue, exception.MissingParameterValue) def get_console_information(self, context, node_id): """Get connection information about the console. :param context: request context. :param node_id: node id or uuid. :raises: UnsupportedDriverExtension if the node's driver doesn't support console. :raises: NodeConsoleNotEnabled if the console is not enabled. :raises: InvalidParameterValue when the wrong driver info is specified. :raises: MissingParameterValue if missing supplied info. """ LOG.debug('RPC get_console_information called for node %s' % node_id) lock_purpose = 'getting console information' with task_manager.acquire(context, node_id, shared=True, purpose=lock_purpose) as task: node = task.node if not getattr(task.driver, 'console', None): raise exception.UnsupportedDriverExtension(driver=node.driver, extension='console') if not node.console_enabled: raise exception.NodeConsoleNotEnabled(node=node_id) task.driver.console.validate(task) return task.driver.console.get_console(task) @messaging.expected_exceptions(exception.NoFreeConductorWorker, exception.NodeLocked, exception.UnsupportedDriverExtension, exception.InvalidParameterValue, exception.MissingParameterValue) def set_console_mode(self, context, node_id, enabled): """Enable/Disable the console. Validate driver specific information synchronously, and then spawn a background worker to set console mode asynchronously. :param context: request context. :param node_id: node id or uuid. :param enabled: Boolean value; whether the console is enabled or disabled. :raises: UnsupportedDriverExtension if the node's driver doesn't support console. :raises: InvalidParameterValue when the wrong driver info is specified. :raises: MissingParameterValue if missing supplied info. :raises: NoFreeConductorWorker when there is no free worker to start async task """ LOG.debug('RPC set_console_mode called for node %(node)s with ' 'enabled %(enabled)s' % {'node': node_id, 'enabled': enabled}) with task_manager.acquire(context, node_id, shared=False, purpose='setting console mode') as task: node = task.node if not getattr(task.driver, 'console', None): raise exception.UnsupportedDriverExtension(driver=node.driver, extension='console') task.driver.console.validate(task) if enabled == node.console_enabled: op = _('enabled') if enabled else _('disabled') LOG.info(_LI("No console action was triggered because the " "console is already %s"), op) task.release_resources() else: node.last_error = None node.save() task.spawn_after(self._spawn_worker, self._set_console_mode, task, enabled) def _set_console_mode(self, task, enabled): """Internal method to set console mode on a node.""" node = task.node try: if enabled: task.driver.console.start_console(task) # TODO(deva): We should be updating conductor_affinity here # but there is no support for console sessions in # take_over() right now. else: task.driver.console.stop_console(task) except Exception as e: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): op = _('enabling') if enabled else _('disabling') msg = (_('Error %(op)s the console on node %(node)s. ' 'Reason: %(error)s') % {'op': op, 'node': node.uuid, 'error': e}) node.last_error = msg else: node.console_enabled = enabled node.last_error = None finally: node.save() @messaging.expected_exceptions(exception.NodeLocked, exception.UnsupportedDriverExtension, exception.InvalidParameterValue, exception.MissingParameterValue) def set_boot_device(self, context, node_id, device, persistent=False): """Set the boot device for a node. Set the boot device to use on next reboot of the node. :param context: request context. :param node_id: node id or uuid. :param device: the boot device, one of :mod:`ironic.common.boot_devices`. :param persistent: Whether to set next-boot, or make the change permanent. Default: False. :raises: NodeLocked if node is locked by another conductor. :raises: UnsupportedDriverExtension if the node's driver doesn't support management. :raises: InvalidParameterValue when the wrong driver info is specified or an invalid boot device is specified. :raises: MissingParameterValue if missing supplied info. """ LOG.debug('RPC set_boot_device called for node %(node)s with ' 'device %(device)s', {'node': node_id, 'device': device}) with task_manager.acquire(context, node_id, purpose='setting boot device') as task: node = task.node if not getattr(task.driver, 'management', None): raise exception.UnsupportedDriverExtension( driver=node.driver, extension='management') task.driver.management.validate(task) task.driver.management.set_boot_device(task, device, persistent=persistent) @messaging.expected_exceptions(exception.NodeLocked, exception.UnsupportedDriverExtension, exception.InvalidParameterValue, exception.MissingParameterValue) def get_boot_device(self, context, node_id): """Get the current boot device. Returns the current boot device of a node. :param context: request context. :param node_id: node id or uuid. :raises: NodeLocked if node is locked by another conductor. :raises: UnsupportedDriverExtension if the node's driver doesn't support management. :raises: InvalidParameterValue when the wrong driver info is specified. :raises: MissingParameterValue if missing supplied info. :returns: a dictionary containing: :boot_device: the boot device, one of :mod:`ironic.common.boot_devices` or None if it is unknown. :persistent: Whether the boot device will persist to all future boots or not, None if it is unknown. """ LOG.debug('RPC get_boot_device called for node %s', node_id) with task_manager.acquire(context, node_id, purpose='getting boot device') as task: if not getattr(task.driver, 'management', None): raise exception.UnsupportedDriverExtension( driver=task.node.driver, extension='management') task.driver.management.validate(task) return task.driver.management.get_boot_device(task) @messaging.expected_exceptions(exception.NodeLocked, exception.UnsupportedDriverExtension, exception.InvalidParameterValue, exception.MissingParameterValue) def get_supported_boot_devices(self, context, node_id): """Get the list of supported devices. Returns the list of supported boot devices of a node. :param context: request context. :param node_id: node id or uuid. :raises: NodeLocked if node is locked by another conductor. :raises: UnsupportedDriverExtension if the node's driver doesn't support management. :raises: InvalidParameterValue when the wrong driver info is specified. :raises: MissingParameterValue if missing supplied info. :returns: A list with the supported boot devices defined in :mod:`ironic.common.boot_devices`. """ LOG.debug('RPC get_supported_boot_devices called for node %s', node_id) lock_purpose = 'getting supported boot devices' with task_manager.acquire(context, node_id, shared=True, purpose=lock_purpose) as task: if not getattr(task.driver, 'management', None): raise exception.UnsupportedDriverExtension( driver=task.node.driver, extension='management') if task.driver.management.get_supported_boot_devices_task_arg: return task.driver.management.get_supported_boot_devices(task) else: LOG.warning(_LW("Driver '%s' is missing a task " "argument to the method " "get_supported_boot_devices() which " "has been deprecated. Please update the code " "to include a task argument."), task.node.driver) return task.driver.management.get_supported_boot_devices() @messaging.expected_exceptions(exception.NodeLocked, exception.UnsupportedDriverExtension, exception.InvalidParameterValue, exception.MissingParameterValue) def set_target_raid_config(self, context, node_id, target_raid_config): """Stores the target RAID configuration on the node. Stores the target RAID configuration on node.target_raid_config :param context: request context. :param node_id: node id or uuid. :param target_raid_config: Dictionary containing the target RAID configuration. It may be an empty dictionary as well. :raises: UnsupportedDriverExtension, if the node's driver doesn't support RAID configuration. :raises: InvalidParameterValue, if validation of target raid config fails. :raises: MissingParameterValue, if some required parameters are missing. :raises: NodeLocked if node is locked by another conductor. """ LOG.debug('RPC set_target_raid_config called for node %(node)s with ' 'RAID configuration %(target_raid_config)s', {'node': node_id, 'target_raid_config': target_raid_config}) with task_manager.acquire( context, node_id, purpose='setting target RAID config') as task: node = task.node if not getattr(task.driver, 'raid', None): raise exception.UnsupportedDriverExtension( driver=task.driver, extension='raid') # Operator may try to unset node.target_raid_config. So, try to # validate only if it is not empty. if target_raid_config: task.driver.raid.validate_raid_config(task, target_raid_config) node.target_raid_config = target_raid_config node.save()

commit_message:
Use sudo for role testing

There are 2 ways to realize the privilege escalation
needed for the gate jobs.

1) Editing the playbooks (and hope to not forget to
write the sudo/become lines for every role)
2) Editing the inventory and set the variable there.

I'm taking the second approach with the minimum set
of variables (become_method is sudo by default and
become_user is root by default).

Change-Id: Iab4a1deda78669fd2a5e3e18c5b86afdffde0cf8

commit_message:
Rename semantic-version dep to semantic_version

The package is actually named semantic_version, not semantic-version. This is
known to cause errors in old pip versions and with non standard setups,
so lets name it correctly.

Change-Id: Ie5709ccc9d67ee221c2c00d6202f8e48b66da80e

commit_message:
Fixing SSH actions to use names of private keys

 * SSH action uses private key names instead of
   private keys themself. All private keys now
   should be in <user-home>/.ssh/, e.g. searching
   of key 'my_key.pem' will be at <user-home>/.ssh/my_key.pem
 * Fixed functional tests
 * Remove sudo while running tests

Closes-Bug: #1507600

Change-Id: I503d78ff541183ce850476229842fa6f20061a00
(cherry picked from commit 56f2d5f4b5603f457e6b4eb5b0a699471b658f9c)

commit_message:
Adding ability to provide name or ID of the flavor in CLI

Node group template now can be created/updated with --flavor
argument that can contain both name or ID of the flavor

Partially implements: blueprint cli-as-openstackclient-plugin

commit_message:
Use sudo for role testing

There are 2 ways to realize the privilege escalation
needed for the gate jobs.

1) Editing the playbooks (and hope to not forget to
write the sudo/become lines for every role)
2) Editing the inventory and set the variable there.

I'm taking the second approach with the minimum set
of variables (become_method is sudo by default and
become_user is root by default).

Change-Id: Ic90ec52b849c8e227084071e80cea87140a049d5

Refactor: Order of security group class names

Per comment in [1], refactor the security group class names to
be in alphabetical order.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/249223

Change-Id: If28a153cdab57c0659ff5c78b276766d4043467f

commit_message:
Handle concurrent deletion in periodic resync thread

See https://github.com/projectcalico/calico/issues/914 for full
discussion.  In summary, for this scenario we need to catch
EtcdKeyNotFound as well as EtcdCompareFailed.

Change-Id: I49652e33639a68c1a68c162bc57b240fbdd0181b
Closes-Bug: #1519795
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-calico refs/changes/96/249796/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Change MODULEPATH env variable in config generator

MODULEPATH is a well known variable from environment-modules package.
This changes to a different one for our case.

UpgradeImpact: MODULEPATH env var in config generator changes to
CONFIG_GENERATOR

Change-Id: I4ef5834c0605d6c7c69514bf6fff189ad1379fb1
Closes-Bug: #1437904
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/60/178860/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: DEFAULT_CONFIG_GENERATOR=cinder.openstack.common.config.generator CONFIG_GENERATOR=${CONFIG_GENERATOR:-$DEFAULT_CONFIG_GENERATOR}python -m $CONFIG_GENERATOR $MODULES $LIBRARIES $FILES > $OUTPUTFILE

commit_message:
cleanup sahara commands

this change will migrate the "sahara" process name to "sahara-all" to
provide greater clarity on what service process is running.

* change start process to sahara-all
* change stop process to sahara-all
* add a sahara-all detection to is_service_enabled
* remove dirname usage in favor of GITDIR environment variable for the
  shutdown script

Change-Id: I80b82edbc6023d4dc28f005fecd8f2138809bbe3

commit_message:
Implement new random name generator for wrapper plugins

This switches all wrapper plugins to use the new consistent random
name generator.

Implements blueprint: consistent-resource-names
Change-Id: I6b27fe2f41d84c1961db3b13cf8ddeeae27a6591
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/87/226387/24 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class NetworkWrapper(utils.RandomNameGeneratorMixin): RESOURCE_NAME_FORMAT = "netwrap_rally_XXXXXXXX_XXXXXXXX" label = self.generate_random_name() kwargs["name"] = self.generate_random_name() "name": self.generate_random_name(), "name": self.generate_random_name() "name": self.generate_random_name(), kwargs["name"] = self.generate_random_name() return NeutronWrapper(clients, task, config=config) return NovaNetworkWrapper(clients, task, config=config)
deleted_lines: class NetworkWrapper(object): label = utils.generate_random_name("rally_net_") if "name" not in kwargs: kwargs["name"] = utils.generate_random_name("rally_router_") "name": utils.generate_random_name("rally_pool_"), "name": utils.generate_random_name("rally_net_") "name": utils.generate_random_name("rally_subnet_"), if "name" not in kwargs: kwargs["name"] = utils.generate_random_name("rally_port_") return NeutronWrapper(clients, config) return NovaNetworkWrapper(clients, config)

added_lines: cliutils.print_dict({"K": "k", "Key": "Value"})| K | k | cliutils.print_dict({"K": "k", "Key": "Value"}, dict_property='Foo', dict_value='Bar')| Foo | Bar || K | k | def test_print_dict_string_sorted(self): orig = sys.stdout sys.stdout = six.StringIO() cliutils.print_dict({"Foo": "k", "Bar": "Value"}) out = sys.stdout.getvalue() sys.stdout.close() sys.stdout = orig expected = '''\ +----------+-------+ | Property | Value | +----------+-------+ | Bar | Value | | Foo | k | +----------+-------+ ''' self.assertEqual(expected, out)

commit_message:
Support shares in sahara cluster templates

Since 0.10.0 python-saharaclient has ability to specify
shares parameter when creating cluster templates.
This patch adds support for this feature to
OS::Sahara::ClusterTemplate resource in Heat.

Change-Id: I44533f79cc8e95e6c41edf08f54f86370d6fd5e2

commit_message:
Decrypting Container Listing

See encryption spec in_progress/at_rest_encryption.html

Decrypts the content-type in the container-listing.
The content-length is modified since decoding decreases length.
When there is "footers" support, the etag will also be decrypted.

Depends on having keymaster middleware and cryptography module.
You can point the following vagrant to this patch:
https://github.com/swiftstack/vagrant-swift-all-in-one/tree/crypto
Alternatively, please follow the instructions
in the proxy-server.conf-sample.  You will also need to add the
fake_footers middleware as well to get the correct functionality.

Co-Authored-By: Alistair Coles <alistair.coles@hp.com>

Change-Id: If7830ed0fc17deb3939492a02a3e07a20f1018c7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/38/214438/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from swift.common.utils import get_logger, config_true_value, json,\ get_obj_persisted_sysmeta_prefix, get_listing_content_type from xml.etree.cElementTree import Element, SubElement, tostring from xml.dom import minidomclass DecrypterContContext(WSGIContext): def __init__(self, decrypter): super(DecrypterContContext, self).__init__(decrypter.app) self.decrypter = decrypter self.logger = decrypter.logger def handle_get(self, req, start_response): app_resp = self._app_call(req.environ) # try: # mod_resp_headers = self.process_resp_headers(req) # except EncryptionException as err: # # TODO - determine the right error code # self.logger.error('Could not process resp headers for cont get') # return HTTPInternalServerError(body=str(err), # content_type='text/plain') # except StopEncryption: # start_response(self._response_status, self._response_headers, # self._response_exc_info) # return app_resp # Only proceed processing if an error has not occurred if self._response_status: resp_int = int(self._response_status[:3]) if not is_success(resp_int): start_response(self._response_status, self._response_headers, self._response_exc_info) return app_resp keys = CryptoUtils.get_keys(req.environ) out_content_type = get_listing_content_type(req) # Pre-process the response body since the content-length will change body_iter = iter(app_resp) new_body = [] new_total_len = 0 try: chunk = body_iter.next() while chunk: if out_content_type == 'application/json': chunk = self.process_json_resp(keys, chunk) elif out_content_type.endswith('/xml'): chunk = self.process_xml_resp(keys, chunk) # else, plaintext: nothing to change if not chunk: # TODO - determine the right error code to return self.logger.error("Could not construct container listing.") raise HTTPInternalServerError("Couldn't construct listing") new_body.append(chunk) new_total_len += len(chunk) chunk = body_iter.next() except HTTPInternalServerError: raise except StopIteration: pass finally: close_method = getattr(body_iter, 'close', None) if callable(close_method): close_method() mod_resp_headers = [ (h, v) for h, v in self._response_headers if h.lower() != 'content-length'] mod_resp_headers.append(('Content-Length', str(new_total_len))) start_response(self._response_status, mod_resp_headers, self._response_exc_info) # TODO - is streaming still necessary? def iter_response(iterable): iterator = iter(iterable) try: chunk2 = iterator.next() while chunk2: yield chunk2 chunk2 = iterator.next() except StopIteration: pass finally: close_method2 = getattr(iterable, 'close', None) if callable(close_method2): close_method2() return iter_response(new_body) def process_json_resp(self, keys, chunk): body_json = json.loads(chunk) mod_body_json = json.dumps([self.decrypt_obj_dict(obj_dict, keys) for obj_dict in body_json]) return mod_body_json def decrypt_obj_dict(self, obj_dict, keys): enc_ct = obj_dict['content_type'] try: enc_ct = base64.b64decode(enc_ct) except TypeError: self.logger.warn("Warn: content_type could not be decoded.") # TODO - find out if this is an error. some functests fall here # return None if '; meta' in enc_ct: # having '; meta' implies encrypted and encoded obj_dict['content_type'] = decrypt_header_val( self.decrypter.crypto, self.decrypter.logger, enc_ct, keys['container'], value_has_meta=True, decode=False) self.logger.debug("decrypted content_type") # TODO - decode/decrypt etag when not using FakeFooters # if etag and (len(etag) > constraints.ETAG_LENGTH): return obj_dict def process_xml_resp(self, keys, chunk): tree = minidom.parseString(chunk) cont = [] child_nodes = None cont_name = 'NO_NAME' for obj in tree.getElementsByTagName('container'): objects = {} for key in ['hash', 'content_type', 'name', 'bytes', 'last_modified', 'sub-dir']: if obj.childNodes: child_nodes = obj.childNodes for index in range(0, child_nodes.length): if index not in objects: objects[index] = {} meta = child_nodes[index].getElementsByTagName(key) if meta: objects[index][key] = \ meta[0].childNodes[0].nodeValue cont.append(objects) cont_name = obj.attributes.getNamedItem("name").value doc = Element('container', name=cont_name) for obj_hash in cont: if child_nodes: for index in range(0, child_nodes.length): if 'subdir' in obj_hash[index]: name = obj_hash[index]['subdir'].decode('utf-8') sub = SubElement(doc, 'subdir', name=name) SubElement(sub, 'name').text = name else: obj_element = SubElement(doc, 'object') for field in ['hash', 'content_type', 'name', 'bytes', 'last_modified']: orig = obj_hash[index][field] try: orig = obj_hash[index][field].decode( 'utf-8') except UnicodeEncodeError: self.logger.warn("xml field %s value %s \ can't be utf-8 decoded." % (field, orig)) # TODO - find out why this happens in functests # return None if field is 'content_type': try: self.logger.debug("xml ct encoded is %s" % orig) orig = base64.b64decode(orig) except TypeError: self.logger.warn("xml content_type %s \ can't be b64 decoded." % orig) # TODO -find out why this happens functests # return None if '; meta' in orig: # having implies encrypted SubElement(obj_element, field).text = \ decrypt_header_val( self.decrypter.crypto, self.decrypter.logger, orig, keys['container'], value_has_meta=True, decode=False) # TODO -
